title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
text: Fit ARIMA model test residuals Ljung-Box statistic

title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
code: ARIMA(x, order = c(0, 0, 0),      seasonal = list(order = c(0, 0, 0), period = NA),      xreg = NULL, include.mean = TRUE, transform.pars = TRUE,      fixed = NULL, init = NULL, method = c("CSS-ML", "ML", "CSS"),      n.cond, optim.control = list(), kappa = 1e6, Box.test.lag=NULL,      Box.test.df = c("net.lag", "lag"),      type = c("Ljung-Box", "Box-Pierce", "rank"))

title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
text: x univariate time series order specification non-seasonal part ARIMA model:      three components (p, d, q) AR order, degree     differencing, MA order. seasonal specification seasonal part ARIMA model, plus     period (defaults 'frequency(x)'). list     components 'order' 'period', specification just     numeric vector length 3 turned suitable list     specification 'order'. xreg Optionally, vector matrix external regressors, must     number rows 'x'. include.mean ARMA model include mean/intercept term?  default     'TRUE' undifferenced series, ignored ARIMA models     differencing. transform.pars Logical.  true, AR parameters transformed ensure     remain region stationarity.  used 'method =     "CSS"'. fixed optional numeric vector length total number     parameters.  supplied, 'NA' entries 'fixed'     varied.  'transform.pars = TRUE' overridden (warning)     AR parameters fixed.  may wise set     'transform.pars = FALSE' fixing MA parameters, especially near     non-invertibility. init optional numeric vector initial parameter values.  Missing values     filled , zeroes except regression coefficients.     Values already specified 'fixed' ignored. method Fitting method: maximum likelihood minimize conditional     sum--squares.  default (unless missing values)     use conditional-sum--squares find starting values, maximum     likelihood. n.cond used fitting conditional-sum--squares: number     initial observations ignore.  ignored less     maximum lag AR term. optim.control List control parameters 'optim'. kappa prior variance (multiple innovations variance)     past observations differenced model.  reduce . Box.test.lag Box.test statistic based 'Box.test.lag'     autocorrelation coefficients whitened residuals.     default maximum following:        round(log(sum(!.na(x)))), recommended Tsay (p. 27). One number parameters estimated, counting       'intercept' model. Box.test.df numeric character variable indicating degrees freedom     ch-square approximation distribution Box.test     statistic.  default 'net.lag' 'Box.test.lag' minus number     relevant parameters estimated.  primary alternative 'lag'     number lags included computation statistic. positive number can also provided. type Box.test 'type' used?  Partial matching used. 'rank' alternative computes 'Ljung-Box' rank(x);  see Burns     (2002) references therein. NOTE:  default 'Ljung-Box' type generally seems     accurate popular earlier 'Box-Pierce', however     default 'Box.test'.

title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
text: 1.  Fit desired model using 'arima'. 2.  Compute desired number lags Box.test 3.  Apply 'AutocorTest' whitened residuals. NOTE:  software adjust degrees freedom   number parameters estimated.  Tsay (2005) Enders (2004) .   need adjust degrees freedom discussed Brockwell   Davis (1990), provide proof describing circumstances   appropriate. , however, asymptotic result, help   simulation studies distribution Ljung-Box statistic,   estimating degrees freedom evaluating goodness fit.  Burns   recommends rank version Ljung-Box test, estimate   degrees freedom.  done simulation know   reference describing , please notify maintainer   package? 4.  'xreg' supplied, compute r.squared.

title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
text: 'arima' object additional 'Box.test' component   'xreg' null, 'r.squared' component. NOTE:  'Box.test' help page R 2.6.1 says, 'Missing values   handled.'  However, 'x' contains NAs, 'ARIMA' still returns   numeric answer seems plausible, least examples.   Therefore, either comment help page wrong (obsolete)   answer can trusted NAs.

Box (1978) 'measure lack fit   time series models', Biometrika, vol. 66, pp. 67-72. Ruey Tsay (2005) Analysis Financial Time Series, 2nd ed. text: Spencer Graves ARIMA{FinTS} wrapper   arima, written R Core Team,   Box.test, written . Trapletti.  John Frain   provided citation proof Brockwell Davis (1990)   degrees freedom approximating chi-square distribution   Ljung-Box statistic adjusted number   parameters estimated.  Michal Miklovic provided citation Enders   (2004).

title: Arima with Ljung-Box — ARIMA
code: ## ## Examples from 'arima' ## lh100 <- ARIMA(lh, order = c(1,0,0)) lh100$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 4) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 5.1851, df = 3, p-value = 0.1587 #>  # df = 3 = round(log(lh)) - 1 # 2 parameters are estimated, but 1 is 'intercept', # so it doesn't count in the 'df' computation  lh500 <- ARIMA(lh, order = c(5,0,0)) lh500$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 6) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 0.48925, df = 1, p-value = 0.4843 #>  # round(log(length(lh))) = 4 # Default Box.test.lag = min(5+1, 4) = 6, # so df = 1;  without the min(5+1, ...), it would be -1. lh500$Box.test$method # lag = 6 #> [1] "Box-Ljung test (lag = 6)"  lh101 <- ARIMA(lh, order = c(1,0,1)) lh101$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 4) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 3.5191, df = 2, p-value = 0.1721 #>  # works with mixed ARMA  USAccD011 <- ARIMA(USAccDeaths, order = c(0,1,1),                    seasonal = list(order=c(0,1,1))) USAccD011$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 4) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 2.7568, df = 2, p-value = 0.252 #>  # df = round(log(length(USAccDeaths))) - 2: # correct 'df' with nonstationary 'seasonal' as well  LakeH200 <- ARIMA(LakeHuron, order = c(2,0,0),                   xreg = time(LakeHuron)-1920) LakeH200$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 5) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 0.59148, df = 2, p-value = 0.744 #>  # correct 'df' with 'xreg' LakeH200$r.squared #> [1] 0.2164241  ## presidents contains NAs ## graphs in example(acf) suggest order 1 or 3 require(graphics) (fit1 <- ARIMA(presidents, c(1, 0, 0))) #>  #> Call: #> stats::arima(x = x, order = order, seasonal = seasonal, xreg = xreg, include.mean = include.mean,  #>     transform.pars = transform.pars, fixed = fixed, init = init, method = method,  #>     n.cond = n.cond, optim.control = optim.control, kappa = kappa) #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1  intercept #>       0.8242    56.1505 #> s.e.  0.0555     4.6434 #>  #> sigma^2 estimated as 85.47:  log likelihood = -416.89,  aic = 839.78 fit1$Box.test #>  #> 	Box-Ljung test (lag = 5) #>  #> data:  fit$resid #> X-squared = 12.718, df = 4, p-value = 0.01274 #>  tsdiag(fit1)  ## ## Example with multiple 'xreg' variables ## tLH <- as.numeric(time(LakeHuron)-1920) tLH2 <- cbind(timeLH.1920 = tLH, time.sq = tLH*tLH)  LakeH200. <- ARIMA(LakeHuron, order=c(2,0,0), xreg=tLH2) LakeH200.$r.squared #> [1] 0.3524303

FALSE omit spike, consistent style Tsay     (2005). ... arguments passed 'plot.acf'.

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
text: Lagrange Multiplier (LM) test autoregressive conditional   heteroscedasticity (ARCH)

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
code: ArchTest (x, lags=12, demean = FALSE)

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
text: x numeric vector lags positive integer number lags demean logical:  TRUE, remove mean computing test     statistic.

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
text: Computes Lagrange multiplier test conditional   heteroscedasticity Engle (1982), described Tsay (2005,   pp. 101-102). provided compatibility 'archTest' S-Plus   script Tsay (p. 102).

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
text: object class 'htest'

title: ARCH LM Test — ArchTest
text: Bernhard Pfaff

code: data(m.intc7303) intcLM <- ArchTest(log(1+as.numeric(m.intc7303)), lag=12) # Matches answer on Tsay (p. 102)

title: Box-Ljung autocorrelation test — AutocorTest
text: Ljung-Box test autocorrelation

title: Box-Ljung autocorrelation test — AutocorTest
code: AutocorTest(x, lag = ceiling(log(length(x))),             type = c("Ljung-Box", "Box-Pierce", "rank"),             df = lag )

title: Box-Ljung autocorrelation test — AutocorTest
text: x numeric vector univariate time series lag statistic based 'lag' autocorrelation coefficients.     Tsay (p. 27-28) says, 'Simulation studies suggest choice     [lag = log(length(x))] provides better power performance.      general rule needs modification analysis seasonal time series     autocorrelations lags multiples seasonality     important.' type Box.test 'type' used?  Partial matching used. 'rank' alternative computes 'Ljung-Box' rank(x);  see Burns     (2002) references therein. NOTE:  default 'Ljung-Box' type generally seems     accurate popular earlier 'Box-Pierce', however     default 'Box.test'. df positive number giving degrees freedom reference     chi-squre distribution used compute p-value     statistic. makes easy call AutocorTest residuals fit     p-value computed reference chi-square     degrees freedom different "lag".  See discussion     degrees freedom 'Box.test   ARIMA.

title: Box-Ljung autocorrelation test — AutocorTest
text: provided compatibility 'autocorTest' S-Plus   script Tsay (p. 30).  wrapper R function   Box.test.

title: Box-Ljung autocorrelation test — AutocorTest
text: list class 'htest' containing following components: statistic number giving value test statistic. paramter number giving degrees freedom approximate     chi-squared distribution test statistic used compute     p.value. p.value p-value test. method character string indicating type test performed.     (df != lag), character string ends     paste("(lag = ", lag, ")", sep="").

Comparison of empirical and normal densities #> # for the monthly simple and log returns of IBM stock #>  #> if(require(logspline)){ #>  #>   m.ibm <- m.ibmvwewsp2603[, "IBM"] #>   dens.ibm.rtns <- logspline(100*as.numeric(m.ibm)) #>   m.log.ibm <- 100*log(1+m.ibm) #>   dens.ibm.logrtns <- logspline(as.numeric(m.log.ibm)) #>  #>   op <- par(mfrow=c(1,2)) #>   plot(dens.ibm.rtns, xlim=c(-40, 40), xlab="simple returns", ylab="density") #>   x.ibm <- seq(-40, 40, len=201) #>   lines(x.ibm, dnorm(x.ibm, mean=100*mean(m.ibm), s=100*sd(m.ibm)), #>         lty="dotted", col="red", lwd=2) #>  #>   plot(dens.ibm.logrtns, xlim=c(-40, 40), xlab="log returns", ylab="density") #>   lines(x.ibm, dnorm(x.ibm, mean=mean(m.log.ibm), s=sd(m.log.ibm)), #>         lty="dotted", col="red", lwd=2) #>   par(op) #> } #> qqnorm(100*m.ibm, datax=TRUE) #> qqnorm(m.log.ibm, datax=TRUE) #>  #> # normal plots may provide a more sensitive evaluation #> # of skewness and kurtosis than density plots #>  #> # The kurtosis here does not look extreme. #> # Similar plots of the daily returns show #> # much more extreme kurtosis. #>  #> # p. 20 #> ## #> ## 1.3.  Processes Considered #> ## #> data(m.gs10) #> data(m.gs1) #> # Figure 1.5.  Time plot of US monthly interest rates  #> op <- par(mfrow=c(2,1)) #> plot(m.gs10, xlab="year", ylab="rate", type="l") #> title("Monthly 10-yr Treasury constant maturity rates") #> plot(m.gs1, xlab="year", ylab="rate", type="l") #> title("Monthly 1-yr Treasury constant maturity rates") #> par(op) #>  #> # p. 21 #> # Figure 1.6.  Time plot of daily exchange rate #> #              between US dollara and Japanese Yen  #> data(d.fxjp00) #> op <- par(mfrow=c(2,1)) #> plot(d.fxjp00, xlab="year", ylab="Yens", type="l") #> plot(diff(d.fxjp00), xlab="year", ylab="Change", type="l") #> par(op) #>  #> # p. 22 #> # Table 1.3.  Descriptive Statistics of Selected US Financial Time Series #> data(m.fama.bond5203) #> (m.bondRtns <- rbind( #>   "1-12 months"=FinTS.stats(100*m.fama.bond5203[, "m1.12"]),  #>   "24-36 months"=FinTS.stats(100*m.fama.bond5203[, "m24.36"]),  #>   "48-60 months"=FinTS.stats(100*m.fama.bond5203[, "m48.60"]),  #>   "61-120 months"=FinTS.stats(100*m.fama.bond5203[, "m61.120"]) )) #>  #> data(m.gs1) #> data(m.gs3) #> data(m.gs5) #> data(m.gs10) #> (m.treasuryRtns <- rbind( #>   "1 year"=FinTS.stats(m.gs1), #>   "3 years"=FinTS.stats(m.gs3), #>   "5 years"=FinTS.stats(m.gs5), #>   "10 years"=FinTS.stats(m.gs10) )) #>  #> data(w.tb3ms) #> data(w.tb6ms) #> (w.treasuryRtns <- rbind( #>   "3 months"=FinTS.stats(w.tb3ms), #>   "6 months"=FinTS.stats(w.tb6ms) ) ) #>  #> #write.table(rbind(m.bondRtns, m.treasuryRtns, w.treasuryRtns), #> #            "Table1-3.csv", sep=",")  # SP statistics in Table 1.2 of Tsay data(d.ibmvwewsp6203) FinTS.stats(100*d.ibmvwewsp6203[, "SP"]) #>        Start  Size       Mean Standard.Deviation   Skewness Excess.Kurtosis #> 1 1962-07-03 10446 0.03312081          0.9453075 -0.9449986        25.76459 #>   Minimum Maximum #> 1  -20.47     9.1

title: Asymptotic PCA — apca
code: # Consider the monthly simple returns of 40 stocks on NYSE and NASDAQ # from 2001 to 2003 with 36 observations. data(m.apca0103) dim(m.apca0103) #> [1] 1440    3 M.apca0103 <- with(m.apca0103,     array(return, dim = c(36, 40),           dimnames = list(as.character(date[1:36]),                           paste("Co", CompanyID[seq(1, 1440, 36)], sep = ""))))  # The traditional PCA is not applicable to estimate the factor model # because of the singularity of the covariance matrix.  The asymptotic # PCA provides an approach to estimate factor model based on asymptotic # properties. For the simple example considered, the sample size is # $T$ = 36 and the dimension is $k$ = 40. If the number of factor is # assumed to be 1, the APCA gives a summary of the factor loadings as # below: # apca40 <- apca(M.apca0103, 1) #> Asymptotic PCA:  Extracting 1 factors from 36 observations on 40 series #>  #> Factor Loading: Summary #>     factor     min 1st Qu. median   mean    Q3   max #> F.1      1 0.06947  0.4322 0.6286 0.6883 1.071 1.612 #> R-squared: Summary #>     min 1st Qu.  median    mean      Q3     max  #> 0.01733 0.21922 0.47494 0.43715 0.57393 0.82652  # # (min, 1st Quartile, median, mean, 3rd quartile, max) = # (0.069, 0.432, 0.629, 0.688, 1.071, 1.612). # # Note that the sign of any loading vector is not uniquely determined # in the same way as the sign of an eigenvector is not uniquely # determined. The output also contains the summary statistics of the # R-squares of individual returns, i.e. the R-squares measuring the # total variation of individual return explained by the factors. For # the simple case considered, the summary of R-squares is (min, 1st # Quartile, median, mean, 3rd quartile, max) = # (0.090,0.287,0.487,0.456,0.574,0.831).

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
text: Find complex conjugate pairs vector complex numbers   return one number pair.

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
code: findConjugates(x, complex.eps = .Machine[["double.eps"]])

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
text: x vector complex numbers complex.eps small positive number used identify complex conjugates:     x[] x[j] considered conjugates (abs(x-Conj(x)) / max(abs(x[], x[j]))) < complex.eps     (abs(x[] - x[j]) > complex.eps.     latter condition excludes repeated roots.

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
text: 1.  Compute normalization m2 = outer(abs(x), abs(x), max). 2.  Compute complex differences       c2 = abs(outer(x, Conj(x), "-")) / m2. 3.  abs(c2) < complex.eps, make sure numbers       duplicate reals via (d2 = abs(outer(x, x, "-"))) > complex.eps.

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
text: complex vector one representative complex pair found

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
text: Spencer Graves Ravi Varadhan

title: Find complex conjugate pairs — findConjugates
code: # none findConjugates(NULL) #> complex(0) findConjugates(numeric(0)) #> complex(0) findConjugates(0:4) #> complex(0) findConjugates(rep(0:1,each=3)) #> complex(0)  # some findConjugates(c(1+1i, 0, 1-1i, 2-2i, 3, 2+2i, NA)) #> [1] 1-1i 2+2i  # Testing with polyroot and solve(polynomial(...)) set.seed(1234) if(require(polynom)){   p <- polynomial(sample(1:10, size=45, rep=TRUE)) # degree 44   z <- solve(p)   findConjugates(z, complex.eps=.Machine$double.eps)   # this identifies all 21 conjugate pairs, R 2.6.0 for Windows    z1 <- polyroot(p)   findConjugates(z1, complex.eps=.Machine$double.eps)   # this only identifies only 3 conjugate pairs, R 2.6.0 for Windows } #> Loading required package: polynom #> complex(0)
